Title: Managing your site
Content:
In this section:

\
  • Learn the different content types
    • \
  • Learn how to move pages within the site
    • \
  • Learn how to hide a webpage
    • \
  • Learn how to delete a webpage
    • \
  • Learn how to view an old version of a page, and roll back to that version.
    • \
  • Learn how to search for a page
    • \
  • Learn how to publish multiple pages
    • \
  • Learn how to set content owners and review dates
    • \
  • Learn how to add \To Do\" items.
    • \

ID:
• Make sure you are in the \"Pages\" section on the navigation tabs. 
    • \
There are many different types of pages in SilverStripe
ClassName:
each with its own functionality and purpose. By now you already know how to create a basic page. It is also possible to change a page from one page type to another.

\

ID: • Page - The most basic page type. It contains content
ClassName: and has no customised functionality or special purpose. Most pages you create on your site will be of this type. \

ID: • Home Page - The Home Page behaves like any other page
ClassName: with the exception that it is the home page for your site - what users will see first if they browse directly to the root of your domain. \

ID: • Error Page - The page displayed when an error is produced by the website. Error pages can be created for individual error types
ClassName: so for example
Created: a 404 \"Page not found\" can look different from a 403 \"Forbidden\" page.\

ID: • Redirector to another page - This page on the website redirects the user to either another page on the same website
ClassName: or a page on an external website.\

ID: • Virtual Page - A virtual page uses the content of another page. This is different from a redirector
ClassName: as a redirector essentially links one location on the website to another
Created: while a virtual page copies the content of the other page. Editing the page the virtual page is based on will
LastEdited: in turn
URLSegment: edit the copied virtual page.\

ID:
• Blog Holders and Blog Entries - See the \"Blogs\" section.
    • \

• Forum Holders and Forum Entries - See the Forums section
    • \

• User Defined Forms - See the Forms section
    • \

ClassName: look in the Contents pane for the page you wish  to change. Click on it
Created:
and head to the \"Behaviour\" tab in the editing pane. You can change the page type from the \"Page type\" drop-down menu. Save your changes by pressing \"Save\" in the bottom right hand corner of the editing pane.

\

ID: \
To move a page within the site
ClassName: head to the Contents pane on the left side of the screen. At the top of the content page should be a check-box next to \"Allow drag & drop reordering.\" By default
Created: this should be turned off
LastEdited:
in order to prevent errant clicks from altering the content of the site by accident. 

\

ID: Clicking on that checkbox will enable drag and drop reordering
ClassName: and you can move a page by clicking on it
Created: and dragging it to its new position in the website.  After you are done moving pages
LastEdited:
it's a good idea to turn off the checkbox next to \"Allow drag & drop reordering\" to prevent the accidental reordering of webpages.

\

ClassName: choose the page you wish to hide in the Contents pane on the left hand side
Created:
then choose the \"Behaviour\" tab in the editing pane.

You can remove your site from being listed in your site's navigation bar by removing the checkmark next to \"Show in menus.\"

You can remove your site from being listed in search results by removing the checkmark next to \"Show in search.\"

After you have made these changes
LastEdited:
hit the \"Save\" button in the bottom right hand of the editing pane.

\

ID: \

ClassName: click on the page you want to delete in the Contents pane. In the Main tab inside the Content tab in the editing pane
Created: you will see in the bottom right hand corner two buttons
LastEdited:
\"Unpublish\" and \"Delete from the draft site.\"

The \"Unpublish\" button will remove the current webpage from the public-facing front end of your site. However
URLSegment: the content will remain as a draft
Title:
and no data will be lost - the page will remain in the CMS.

The \"Delete from Draft Site\" button will remove the current webpage from the back-end CMS
MenuTitle: but if you have previously published it
Content:
it will not be removed from the public-facing front-end of your site.

To completely delete a webpage
MetaDescription:
then click on \"Delete from the draft site.\"

\

ClassName: click \"Batch Actions\" on the top of the  content pane. Each page in the page tree in the Contents pane should now  have a checkbox next to it. Check all the pages you want to delete.  (And perhaps more importantly
Created:
make sure NOT to check those pages you do not want to delete.)

From the drop-down menu at the top of the contents pane
LastEdited: choosing \"Delete from Published Site\" will remove the  page from the public-facing portion of the website
URLSegment:
but retain a copy of those pages in the backend CMS.

Choosing \"Delete from draft site\" will remove the page from the backend CMS
Title:
but the page will remain on the public-facing portion of the website.

To completely delete multiple pages
MenuTitle: you must do both. The order of  deletions in \"Batch Actions\" does not matter
Content: though it's generally a  good idea to delete from the published site first
MetaTitle:
then delete from the draft site.

\

ID:
Click on the page you want to view a previous version of in the Contents pane's \"Page Tree.\"

At the bottom of the Contents pane
ClassName:
you will find a small grey bar marked \"Page Version History\" with a chevron. Click on those chevrons to bring up the Page Version History window in the Contents pane.

\

ID: Click on any of the listed versions to look at the content of the page. If you want to view draft versions of pages as well as published versions

click the \"Show unpublished versions\" checkbox.

with a strikethrough through any text that was deleted.

and click on \"Roll back to this version\" in the editing pane.

and you can type any text to search your pages for that text. Pressing search will show only positive results in the Page Tree on the Contents pane.

click \"Batch Actions\" on the top of the content pane. Each page in the page tree in the Contents pane should now have a checkbox next to it. Check all the pages you want to publish.

From the drop-down menu at the top of the contents pane

URLSegment: web-content-best-practices
Title: Web content best practices
Content:
In this section:

\
  • Learn how to make your site search-engine friendly
    • \
  • Learn how to make your content accessible
    • \
  • Other web best practices
    • \

Making your content search engine friendly

\

Much of your website traffic will come from search engines. To ensure your website is findable, you need to write and mark up your content in a way that allows the search engine to present the most relevant results. Put another way, search engine friendly content will get more relevant traffic to your site.

\

What makes a site search engine friendly? Two things:

\
  • Relevant content.
    • \
  • A site built to standards, in other words, in an accessible way.
    • \

Search engine friendliness and accessibility are very closely related - you can think of Google as just another blind user.

\

SilverStripe CMS automatically does a number of things that make your site search-engine friendly and accessible. As a website editor, you don't have to concern yourself with the code side of things. However, there is much you can do to when it comes to your content:

\
  • Post relevant content. This may sound obvious, but it's the most important thing you can do as an editor. If your content is relevant to your users, your site wil rank higher for the search terms they are using.
    • \
  • If it's important to you to rank highly for specific phrases, it's key to literally mention these phrases in the first paragraph of relevant pages on the site. The absolute best way to rank number one is to have dedicated pages for these phrases. In the title of these pages would be the phrases you wish to rank for.
    • \
  • Use CMS tools for to properly mark up your content.
    • \
  • Ensure correct spelling across all your content - typos make the site rank lower.
    • \
  • Ensure there are no broken links in your site - again, broken links will make your site rank lower.
    • \
  • Provide text alternatives for media content, such as ALT text for your images, since search engines can't see images, just their descriptions.
    • \

URLs, page names, titles and navigation labels

\

When you first create a new page, start by entering its name in the Page name field on the Main tab. SilverStripe CMS automatically populates a number of other fields based on that name. You can leave them as is, or change them individually.

\

Why should you care? It's useful to know where and how the different names are displayed.

\


\

ID:
• The Page name is what generates the main headline (the <h1> tag) for the page's content.
    • \
• The Navigation label is what appears in your site's navigation. Sometimes when you have a lengthy page name
ClassName: it makes sense to create a shortened navigation label.\

ID: • The URL gets generated based on the page name
ClassName: using the words and dashes. Human-readable URLs make a page more easily found by search engines. Most of the time
Created: the URL that SilveStripe CMS generates will be fine
LastEdited: but you can manually change it if necessary.\

ID: • The Title is what appears in the browser's title bar and tabs
ClassName: and in Google's search results page (the <title> meta tag.) Page titles should be unique
Created: and shouldn’t exceed 65 characters (spaces included)
LastEdited: as Google only shows the first 65 characters in search result titles.\

ID:
Your website developer will have configured your SilverStripe site for either simple or hierarchical or URLs.

\
Simple URLs only use a single level of depth. For example
ClassName: a page for a staff member might be called \"John Smith\"
Created: and its URL would be http://website.com/john-smith. Simple URLs are short and memorable
LastEdited: however
URLSegment:
you are more likely to have multiple pages with the same name.

\

ID: If a URL is already in use
ClassName: the CMS will generate URLs with numbers
Created: e.g.
LastEdited: /staff-members-1
URLSegment: /staff-members-2
Title:
etc.

\

ClassName: it's a good idea to manually change the URLs to something more meaningful
Created: such as /staff-members-berlin
LastEdited:
/staff-members-hong-kong.

\

ID: Hierarchical URLs provide a logical path for a page as it exists in the site's structure. In our example
ClassName:
this might be http://website.com/offices/new-york/staff/john-smith

\

ID: Meta tags also make your web page more findable. The Description meta attribute should contain a concise and relevant summary of what the page contains. This will show in search engine results
ClassName:
and helps visitors understand the content of the page.

\

ID: Keywords can be used to further describe your page
ClassName: and help to make your page more findable by search engines.  Think about the words users would type in a search engine to find your pages
Created:
and make sure that your page includes those words within it.

\

ID: Google doesn’t like repetition of keywords and phrases in the title
ClassName: description or keywords.  It sees this as 'keyword stuffing'
Created:
which is looked at as search engine spam (not good!) Avoid this.

\

ID: SilverStripe CMS generates clean HTML code when you type your content into the CMS. However
ClassName: often you already have content in another format
Created: such as Microsoft Word
LastEdited:
which you need to simply transfer into the CMS.

\

ID: Avoid cutting and pasting directly from a word processor with the standard cut and paste functions. Always \"Paste from Word\" if using Microsoft Word
ClassName:
or \"Paste as Text\" if using another word processor. Word processors tend to do poor jobs of creating web markup code and often insert extraneous code which make your site less search-engine friendly and accessible.

\

ID: An accessible website means that it can be viewed by the widest audience possible. Accessibility not only refers to people with physical disabilities (such as blind users)
ClassName: but also people with cognitive
Created: learning or motor skills disabilities
LastEdited: and people who access your site with mobile devices or old
URLSegment: outdated technology. Lastly
Title: as mentioned previously
MenuTitle:
search engines can be considered disabled users in the sense that they can't' see your design or images or interact with your site.

\

ID:
Accessibility is important for a number of reasons:

\

• Ethical—being inclusive is the right thing to do and has a positive impact on how your audience perceives you or your organisation.
    • \
<li>Business—sites that can be used by everyone have a larger audience. They are more findable and therefore generate more traffic/business. Accessible  sites are also easier to maintain
ClassName: resulting in fewer ongoing costs.\

ID: <li>Legal—many governments require websites to comply with certain standards. Details depend on your country
ClassName: however
Created: typically the guidelines are based on the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines developed by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C.) \

ID: Accessibility is not something you implement once and then have it. There is an infinite number of types of disability
ClassName: platforms
Created: devices
LastEdited: configurations
URLSegment:
so you have to choose to what level you want to comply.

\

ID: The more you know about your users
ClassName: the better. Web stats
Created: such as Google Analytics
LastEdited: can help you find out about your users' most frequently used browsers and operating systems. User research can help to learn more about how users with disabilities interact with the site - but that's costly and often not an option. Automated tools can help and are a useful first step as they look for all the obvious issues and generate a list of problems. However
URLSegment: it still requires a person to assess and interpret the results and make decisions about items flagged by the automated tools. For example
Title: you can use an automated tool to check whether all your images have alternative text
MenuTitle:
but you as the editor of your site need to determine if the text in the alt attribute is descriptive and appropriate.

\

ID:
The following paragraphs describe some of the quick wins—things you can do easily to greatly increase the accessibility of your site.

\

ClassName: always provide alternative text that can serve as a placeholder in case the image itself cannot be displayed. Alternative text is often referred to as the \"ALT tag\"
Created: although that's not technically correct :-). Alternative text is important for those who cannot see the actual image
LastEdited: such as vision impaired users
URLSegment: people with text-only browsers
Title: or search engine
MenuTitle:
and it should be meaningful and describe what the image shows.

\

ClassName: you may also want to add title text for your image. Title text is for additional information about your image
Created: such as the name of the photographer
LastEdited:
or the date when it was taken. The title text appears as a tooltip when the user hovers over the image.

\

ID: \
Mark up your headings by selecting the right heading style from the Format dropdown. Using headings properly gives your content hierarchy and
ClassName: for example
Created: allows users with screen readers to skip ahead to the next heading. Note that Heading 1 will be the title of your page
LastEdited: and all lower-level headings should be nested properly (e.g.
URLSegment: Heading 3 should be within a Heading 2 section
Title:
etc.)

\

ID: \

ClassName:
select either bullets (unordered list) or numbers (ordered list) - don't use dashes or asterisks to mark up lists.

\

make sure your link text (the part of your content that's clickable) is meaningful and relates to the page you're linking to. Don't use \"click here\" or \"read more\" as they don't tell the user where your link is going. Think about what would make sense for someone who has the link text read out to them by a screen reader.

\

ID: You may also want to add a link description. Especially if your link text isn't too clear
ClassName: you can provide information about the link's target. Again
Created: this will be read out by screen readers
LastEdited:
and the browser will display it as a tooltip when the user hovers over the link.

\

ID: \

ClassName: such as Flash
Created: audio or video content
LastEdited: document attachments or animations
URLSegment: make sure this content is accessible to users who can't see or hear it
Title: or who don't have the software to view it. How exactly you do this will depend on the kind of content and how critical it is to your site and your users. Typical alternatives would be transcripts
Content: of PDF documents)

ID: If your site uses graphs to convey information
ClassName:
also provide text-based summaries that describe the information displayed in the graphs.

\
make sure you mark them up so that screen readers can interpret them correctly (for example
Created:
mark header rows/columns as such.) It's also a good idea to provide a text-based summary of the information contained in the table.

\

ID: When you embed images in your content
ClassName: always specify width and height. This allows the browser to start rendering the page before downloading the actual image
Created: which speeds up  page loading. SilverStripe CMS prepopulates the image dimensions automatically
LastEdited: so unless you want to change them
URLSegment:
you don't have to do anything special.

In this section:

\
  • Understand workflow
    • \
  • Learn how to request publication (as a content author)
    • \
  • Learn how to publish content (as a publisher)
    • \
  • Learn how to schedule content to be automatically published or unpublished at a future time
    • \

In its most basic sense, workflow means that new content or changes to existing content need to go through an approval process before they get published to the live site. This works by limiting access to certain parts of the workflow to certain users, using Roles and Security Groups.  

\

Generally, you use Roles to define what a class of people can do, and Security Groups to determine where in the site the users have access.  

\

SilverStripe CMS Workflow is available in two versions: 2-step, and 3-step.

\

In two step workflow, the author creates or edits content, and then requests publication. The publisher either publishes the content or does not, either sending it back for further edits or deleting it completely.

\

In three step workflow, there is an additional approval step, where someone can approve content for publication, but not actually publish.  

\

Requesting publication (authors)

\

Depending on what rights they have, content creators may only have rights to \request publication
MetaTitle:
\" and not to publish pages themselves.

\

Title: Creating and editing content
Content:
In this section

\
  • Learn how to create a new page.
    • \
  • Learn how to write content for that page.
    • \
  • Learn how to describe that content for site navigation and search optimization.
    • \
  • Learn how to create hyperlinks.
    • \
  • Learn how to save your page as a draft.
    • \
  • Learn how to publish your page to the live site. 
    • \

Before we begin

\
  • Make sure you are in the \Pages\" section on the Navigation Tabs. 
    • \

ID: \

ClassName: first decide where in the site you want your page to be.  If you are creating a new \"subpage
Created: \" click on the parent page in the left-hand Contents Pane you would like to create the subpage in. If you want your site to be in the top level navigation for your site
LastEdited:
you should click on the root of the site - the first item listed in the Contents Pane.  

\

ID: On the top of the Contents Pane
ClassName: you will find a button marked \"Create.\"  Click it
Created:
and a drop-down menu will show up. 

\

ID: \

ClassName: \" but if it's not
Created:
go ahead and select \"Page.\"  Then hit the \"Go\" button.

\

ID: You will notice that a new page has been created
ClassName: with the name of \"New Page.\" (You will also notice it's color
Created:
Yellow. Yellow pages are \"new\" and have never been published.)

\

ID:
Simply click on the new page in the content page to bring it up in the editing pane. 

\
Don't worry if you create your page in the \"wrong\" place.  Pages can be moved and re-ordered easily
ClassName:
and we will cover that under \"Managing Your Site.\" 

\
to edit content
Created: you want to click on the \"Content\" tab if it it not already selected
LastEdited:
and then the \"Main\" page. 

\

ID:
Here you will be presented with three forms.  

\
\
The first is for the Page Name - this will define what the page will be known as in the CMS
ClassName: but it will also be used to form the \"default\" navigation label and URL for the page
Created:
though both can be changed manually.  

\

ClassName: you will find the Navigation Label.  This will define what the page will show up as when listed in site navigation on the public-facing front page of your site. If you fill in the Page Name first
Created: it will automatically put the page name in the navigation label field. It is usually
LastEdited: but not always
URLSegment: a good idea to leave it the same.  If you wish to change the navigation label but not the page name
Title:
you can do so here.  

\

ClassName:
there is the Content box.  This will contain the bulk of text to appear on your webpage.  Type the text that will appear in the page on the Website.  You may also feel free to use the formatting toolbar at the top of the content screen in order to format your page the way you would prefer.  

\

most items in the formatting toolbar will behave much like they would in any word processor.  There are a few exceptions. 

\
the Styles drop-down box allows you to add certain styles to a page.  This is primarily used to add image styles to a link of downloadable content
Created: for example
LastEdited: links to PDF or Word documents
URLSegment: Excel spreadsheets
Title:
or images. 

\

ID: The Paragraph drop-down box allows you to choose a format for that paragraph in HTML code.  Most typed paragraphs will be in the normal \"paragraph\" format
ClassName:
but there are also six levels of \"headings.\"  

\

ID: Headings represent the outline organization of a document. H1 is generally considered the highest level of the document
ClassName: while H6 is the lowest level. By using the \"Heading\" paragraph formats
Created: it will automatically make all paragraphs marked with the same heading number the same format.  And
LastEdited: if you want to change the style of your page at a later date
URLSegment: your web designer will only need to change the heading definitions in one place
Title:
rather than changing the format of multiple headings in your text individually.  This can be a big timesaver!  

\

ID: The \"Blockquote\" button is used to offset text in what those in the newspaper industry call \"pull-quotes.\" Simply highlight the text you want to offset
ClassName:
and press the blockquote button.  

\
the \"Insert Horizontal Ruler\" button will insert a horizontal line on the page
Created: and the \"Insert Special Character\" button
LastEdited: marked by the Greek Omega symbol
URLSegment: is used to insert special characters into the text.  This is useful for foreign loanwords with special symbols
Title: such as \"resumé
Content: \" and metal umlauts

ID: There is one other button that needs explanation.  That is the button marked \"HTML.\" If you want to go in and edit the source code of the page directly
ClassName: pressing the HTML button will bring up the HTML source of the page.  It is recommended that you only do this if you have a good knowledge of HTML formatting. This can be useful when you need to directly add some source code to a page
Created: for example
LastEdited:
when embedding YouTube videos. 

\

ID:
Cutting & pasting from a Word Processor
You may want to bring some text you have already written on a word processor
ClassName:
such as Microsoft Word into your page content.

\
you can paste any text from a \"plain text editor\" such as Notepad.exe on Windows systems
Created: TextEdit.app on Macintosh systems
LastEdited: and gEdit on Ubuntu Linux
URLSegment:
et al.

\

ID:
Pasting directly from most word processors or other application often inserts bits of \"rich text\" formatting code that usually doesn't work well with the HTML markup code used on Websites. SilverStripe offers two solutions to this problem.

\

The first is \"Paste as Text.\" [Screenshot].  Paste As Text removes all formatting from copied text before adding it to the website.

\

ClassName: \" where SilverStripe takes the \"rich text\" formatting code from Microsoft Word
Created: and translates that into HTML markup code. However
LastEdited: this only works with Microsoft Word
URLSegment: and not with other word processors such as OpenOffice.org
Title: Word Perfect

ID: It's not just enough to create good content that informs your readers. You also need to let your readers find the content they're looking for. You can help your readers find your content by adding metadata. Metadata is page-specific blocks of text
ClassName: normally hidden from general browsers
Created:
which search engines use to classify the page on the internet.  

\

ID: In the Editing Pane for the page you want to describe
ClassName: under the \"Content\" tab
Created: and next to the \"Main\" tab where you would edit text content for the body of the page is a tab marked \"Metadata.\" In the Metadata tab
LastEdited: you can change the site URL
URLSegment: if you wish
Title: to make it more SEO-friendly.  You can also enter a description and keywords for your site.  If your web manager has asked you to add any additional metadata
MenuTitle:
you can do so from this page as well. 

\

ID: To create a hyperlink in a webpage
ClassName: highlight the text you wish to make a link in the Editing Pane
Created:
and press the \"Insert Link\" button on the toolbar.  This will bring up the Link sidebar on the right side of the screen.

\

ID:
Creating a link to another page on the site

\
To link to another page on the site
ClassName:
choose \"Page on the Site\" from the list of options on the top of the Link sidebar.  You can then select the page you want to link to from the drop-down box.  Your \"Link Text\" should be automatically filled in with the highlighted text in the Editing Pane.  Check \"Open link in a new window\" if you would like to have the link opened in a new window when the user clicks on it.

\
to insert the link
Created:
click the \"Insert Link\" button on the Link sidebar.

\

ID: \

Creating a link to an external page

\
To link to a page on another website
ClassName:
choose \"Another Website\" from the list of options on the top of the Link sidebar.  You can then paste or type in the URL of the webpage you would like to link to in the \"URL\" field on the sidebar.  Your \"Link Text\" should be automatically filled in with the highlighted text in the Editing Pane.  Check \"Open link in a new window\" if you would like to have the link opened in a new window when the user clicks on it.

\
to insert the link
Created:
click the \"Insert Link\" button on the Link sidebar.

\

ID: \
There are different processes for \"internal\" and \"external\" links because when pages on a SilverStripe installation are moved or deleted
ClassName:
the links in other pages on the site are automatically changed to the new pages location.  This allows you to quickly move pages around without worry of breaking the site's structure or checking every page in the site for broken links.

\

ID: If you enter in an internal link URL in the external link field
ClassName:
SilverStripe CMS is usually smart enough to change the link to an internal link.

\

ID:
Creating a link to an email address

\

ClassName:
choose \"Email Address\" from the list of options on the top of the Link sidebar.  You can then paste or type in the e-mail address that you would like to link to.  Your \"Link Text\" should be automatically filled in with the highlighted text in the Editing Pane. 

\
to insert the link
Created:
click the \"Insert Link\" button on the Link sidebar.

\

ID: One other option is to hyperlink to a document (a PDF file
ClassName: DOC file
Created: audio file
LastEdited: video file
URLSegment: or any sort of file that is not a webpage) that you have uploaded to your website. This is a more advanced topic
Title: however
MenuTitle:
and we will cover it in \"Working with Images and Documents.\"

\

ID: To save your page as a draft
ClassName: simply hit the \"Save\" button (not \"Save and Publish
Created: \" if it is available) on the bottom right hand corner of the Editing Pane. Saving your page as a draft allows you to preview the page on a \"Draft Site\" available to you and others who have access to the CMS
LastEdited:
but does not publish the page to the live website.  

\

ID: After you save your page as a draft
ClassName:
you can preview the page by clicking on \"Draft Site\" in the View Bar on the bottom left hand corner of the screen. 

\

or submitting your page for publication:

\

ID: If your website has a workflow module installed
ClassName: and you do not have administrative privileges
Created:
you can submit your draft changes for publication to your site's administrator by pressing the \"Request Publication\" button.  This will send notification to your site's administrator that the webpage is ready for review.  

\

ID: If you do not have the workflow module installed
ClassName: or you are the site's administrator
Created: you can publish the page at any time by hitting the \"Save and Publish\" button.  Once the \"Save and Publish\" button is pressed
LastEdited: that information will go out to the live web
URLSegment: so be careful that you are not publishing embarrassing typos
Title: confidential information
MenuTitle:
or anything you would generally get rebuked by your organization's legal council for publishing. 

\

ID:
You can view the published site directly by clicking on \"Published Site\" in the View Bar on the bottom left hand corner of the screen. 

\

Roles are collections of permissions.  For example
Title: you might create an  editor role to give a group read/write access to all content
MenuTitle: or a  \"contributor\" role who has the right to add content to the CMS but not  to publish it
Content: or a \"spectator\" role which gives a person a right to  view the backend of the CMS
MetaTitle:
but not any ability to edit it.

Security groups are collections of users
MetaDescription: and whatever permissions they  have apply to a subset of pages. So
ExtraMeta: the marketing team  could have access to the parts of the website dealing with marketing
ShowInMenus:
and the development team could have access to the parts of the website dealing with development.

One of the ways that the two can be used together is to assign similar roles to different groups.  You only need to define an \"editor\" role once
ShowInSearch: but by applying the \"editor\" role to different groups with  different access to different pages
HomepageForDomain: so if you assigned the \"editor\"  role to both the marketing team and development team security groups
ProvideComments: the marketing team would be able to edit the marketing pages
Sort: and the  development team would be able to edit the development pages
LegacyURL:
but they would not be able to edit each other's pages.

As a general rule of thumb
HasBrokenLink: and Security Groups define who can do it

ID: • Administrator (someone who has full rights for the management of the site

the CMS allows you to create as many different roles as are appropriate for your organisation.

\" (They can change the location for a page in the site tree and so manage the site structure and navigation.)

The SilverStripe Subsites module allows you to manage multiple related sites through a single CMS interface. Because all sites run on a single installation of SilverStripe

content and assets.

Groups can have access to all sites

\

\

\

ID: You can create a user by clicking on the \"Members\" tab in the Editing Pane
ClassName: there is a button on the bottom right hand corner
Created: labeled \"Add Member.\" Press it
LastEdited:
and a form will pop-up.  

Here
URLSegment: in the Main tab in the popup
Title:
you can edit the user's details. The two most important parts of the user details are the user's email (which is also used as a login) and password.

If you have a forum
MenuTitle: you can also alter administrative settings for forums as well
Content: granting administrative access for the forum as a whole from the \"Forum\" tab
MetaTitle:
and assign the user moderation powers over specific forums from the \"Moderated Forums\" tab. You can also assign the user to one or more security groups from the Groups tab.  (Security groups are covered below.)

\

\
\

ClassName: they are only removed from that group
Created: not from the  system.  To fully  delete a user

Title: Basic overview
Content:
The SilverStripe CMS is arranged in five sections.  

\

\

ID: The Navigation Tabs allow you to navigate to the main groups in SilverStripe CMS. Here
ClassName: you can choose to manage pages
Created: your stock of files and images
LastEdited: or your website's comments. You can also get reports on pages
URLSegment:
and get help.  Some modules and options will add additional tabs here. Click on the relevant tab to display the associated information in the current window.

\

ID: Specific tabs may change depending on what modules are installed. However
ClassName:
the following tabs are part of a typical SilverStripe installation:

\

ID: This section enables you to access and edit the content of the pages on your website. On this tab
ClassName:
two extra \"sub-tabs\" are displayed in the left pane that enable you to display a History of editing events and a list of Reports incorporated within the system. 

\
the screen will display a list of all folders containing uploaded files and images. This hierarchical view enables you to locate and select the file you wish to edit
Created:
delete or move.

\

ID: If you have page comments enabled anywhere on the site
ClassName:
you can use this section to view and moderate them.

\

ID: This section shows reports for your site
ClassName: for example
Created: pages with broken links. What you see in this section will depend on which version of SilverStripe you are running
LastEdited:
and what modules you have installed.

\

ID: The Security section enables you to set up and administrate users and user groups. The various security groups are displayed in the left pane and the details of the selected group are displayed in the right pane. Amongst other things
ClassName:
this enables you to add and remove members from selected groups and control the access these users have to pages.

\

ID:
Help provides direct access to SilverStripe user help. This is the site you are looking at right now!

\
The Contents Pane displays the contents of the currently selected navigation tab in a hierarchical format.  For example
ClassName: when looking at the \"Pages\" navigation tab
Created: the Contents pane will show you a sitemap
LastEdited: listing all of the pages on the site. Pages can be nested
URLSegment: so to expand the view to include subpages
Title: click on the \"+\" icon.  If you wish to collapse the views
MenuTitle:
you can click on the \"-\" icon.  

\

Created: if you were to click on a webpage in the Contents pane
LastEdited: the Editing Pane would show you the content on that page
URLSegment: and let you edit it.  When editing content
Title: the Editing Pane is \"WYSIWYG\" - or \"What You See Is What You Get.\" You can use the toolbar in the editing pane to edit the webpage's content
MenuTitle:
much like you would in a word processor.
